name: Connecting through film
description: Film acts like a time capsule to our collective past. Capturing our most treasured moments with family has never been more accessible, with technology right at our fingers.

key_work.title: The Koorie Oral History Program and the Bill Onus family archive
key_work.brief_description: Koorie people record ourselves as a means of self-representation, to destroy stereotypes and to ensure that we are not erased. These films from the Koori Oral History Program and the Bill Onus family archive preserve our culture and kinship for future generations.

end.title: Bill Onus hosting Alcheringa
end.brief_description: To Bill Onus, sharing his culture was an act of resistance and reclamation of power. Through Forgotten People(1967) and Alcheringa (1962), Bill demonstrated his ongoing commitment to self-representation through screen culture.

links.description: Bill Onus is one of the first known Aboriginal filmmakers with a recently discovered silent 1946 film credited to him. Bill documented Aboriginal life on film, and was a trailblazer in self-representation. Some films from his family archive feature in the Memory Garden display.

start.title: My Survival as an Aboriginal
start.credit_line: Courtesy the Coffey family and Martha Ansara / the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia / Ballad Films
start.brief_description: Essie Coffey OAM was a Murawarri activist, advocate and filmmaker concerned about the influence of white culture and education on Indigenous children. As seen in her groundbreaking documentary, My Survival as an Aboriginal (1978), she taught culture to her community.

constellations_other.name: Women in charge
constellations_other.description: Across documentary, film, TV, and visual art, Aboriginal women have led how they will be represented on-screen.

constellations_other.name: Jedda: Uneven ground, the road to on-screen diversity
constellations_other.description: Jedda was the first fully funded Australian feature to be shot on colour film. It was also the first Australian film with Aboriginal actors in lead roles, however, it reflects a deeply problematic time in Australian history.
